title: Potentially awesome
text: This is quite an amazing museum, one that I'd like to bring my nephew to some day. There are so many different areas that there's bound to be one for everyone. Like other reviewers have said, it is dated and is in the process of being renovated with a few other faults: 90% of signage and information is written in German which was kind of annoying as I lost interest in areas as I couldn't read anything. There's also way too much information and items to see in each of the rooms that it becomes too much and is an overload which also contributed to loss of interest. A selection of the most important items presented in chronological order would help visitors get more out of the purpose of each section and it's evolution, right now it's kind of all just lumped together. The other thing with this was that you didnt know where to start and what kind of story each area is trying to tell. I liked the mining area quite a bit. One reviewer said it felt like being transported back to the olden days but I think that's the entire purpose? You actually get a feel for what it was like back then and was probably one of the best bits of the museum. Again, too many items and no English descriptions of things meant I just walked straight through this section despite it being a highlight. A more uniform signage across the museum of interactive things for kids would be good. I would come back once it's been renovated as it really is a great museum that would be even better with some changes. I went around 10am when there was no line and little visitors. By 11-12pm, there was a line around the corner of the museum shop and large groups already in the museum. Try and get there early.

text: Huge museum, but quite dated and clearly showing its age.1) Antiquated museum concept. It feels like walking into a museum from the 70's. The English labels (when present) are in even smaller print and italicized, making them very difficult to read. Some of the English labels are incomprehensible or plain wrong (i.e. world population 5.8 million instead of billion). Entire rooms are in German only. There is no cohesive narrative for the visitor to follow. Most of the very few interactive displays and simulations were either closed or not working. Currently several sections are closed for renovation, and one can only hope they are being entirely revamped. 2) The data and information provided in many sections are also quite outdated. The Environment section provides world population data as of 1997, some other sections provide information accurate as of 1992. Pluto was downgraded from planet in 2006: in the relevant section there is a typed sheet of paper in German only, taped over the previous panel.3) Ticketing: Single tickets cost 14 euros, but the ticket office has a credit card minimum of 20 euros! Unbelievable. Fortunately, one can buy a ticket online with no surcharge, even though it's not a friendly system (registration required, browser needed).Overall quite disappointing.

text: Today, at 11am, I visited the Deustsches Museum MÃ¼nchen with a friend and I cannot ignore the  impolite and unprofessional way we were treated at the ticket's desk. She asked us all the money, in order to refund the tickets, so we gave her 11 euros (10euros-bill + 1euro-coin), she saved the 10 euros bill, gave us a 5-euros-bill and a coin (that means she stored extra 5 euros) and shouted at us in the most impolite manners I have ever seen at a museum "Dann gehen Sie einfach weh!". We felt so outraged that we ran to the information desk, we wrote a complaint and were told that the enterprise that runs the ticket's desk is not the museum's resposablity, so we could not refund our tickets. This experience marked my visit very negatively, never in my life I have seen this incompetence and impoliteness at the museum's ticket desk.

title: Nice, but disappointing
text: While the museum is quite large with exhibitions on many subjects, we felt that it wasn't that interesting. In addition, the museum was less interactive than we were led to believe.Overall, I don't feel that it was in any way extraordinary.As a side note, we ate at the cafeteria and the food there was plain bad. I'd highly recommend not eating there and find some restaurant nearby

title: A huge, interesting museum, with quite a few outdated exhibits
text: I spent the better part of a day in the Deutsches Museum in Munich. It is a huge place, divided into multiple areas of interest and disciplines. Currently it is undergoing significant renovations and updates . So each section is very different.The physics and atomic power segments are outdated. Most recent calamity is Chernobyl, and (most) details date back to 1996. Seeing computerized exhibits done on CRT screens make you smile. Same thing about wind  and sun power exhibits - so much has changed since the exhibits were prepared!On the other hand, the glass section is up to date, and beautifully done.Many of the texts (in the older exhibits) are in German only, which is disappointing.So ups and downs, but a very impressive museum all the same.

title: Excellent Tech - Sadly some exhibits closed.
text: I last visited in 2008 and was thrilled with the rocketry exhibits. I made a special trip from Poland to revisit it this Sept. and was eagerly looking forward to the V2 section of the Museum. After visiting the entire museum I had to ask and was told that they hoped it would reopen in 2021. Darn.My engineering expertise is embedded microelectronic systems. They are planning a new section to open in 2020 but at least teased us with a wonderful collection of computers ranging from the abacus to an excellent cross-section of mainframes and early super computers. I will plan to revisit in 3-5 years.It was quite noticeable which sections still needed renovation. All newer exhibits included both the German and English text (Thank You!!!) and were sometimes difficult to read but still more enjoyable than the ,Deutsch Only, section even though I can read both.I am still impressed with the depth and breadth of the detail they put into the Mining section and would believe that younger children might find that interesting even if they don't understand the ramifications.The early flight section was well done and hopefully will tie in with the modern space exploration section when it reopens. I waited 11 years to return and as a MIT trained engineer still appreciated much of what I saw and learned.

text: It is a very nice museum with a lot and interesting displays. Among the others, it has a mining section, machinery, airplanes, a kids section etc. The gift shop has many items but in my opinion they are high priced. Another issue is that all the exhibits are explained in German and some of them in English. However, for technology and design advocates, it definately worths a visit.

title: Massive collection but very hot and airless
text: I visited on a Saturday afternoon and it was fairly busy. Weather had cooled down to 25 after having been up to 33 earlier in the week. I found virtually all areas very warm and some were uncomfortably hot and airless. Windows had been opened at  some locations but this didn't seem to help much. Galleries on upper floors were particularly bad. Had the inside temperature and ventilation been better I would have given a mark of 5. The number of exhibits (some very large) was very impressive and had the conditions inside been comfortable I would have stayed for much longer.Unlike the Verkehrsmuseum (at a separate location) there were very few English descriptions which didn't help. You could download an app which gives some English commentary but this was for very few items widely dotted around museum. Disappointed that the unpleasant conditions inside made me cut my visit short. I would like to have stayed for much longer. If you don't like hot stuffy museums I regretfully suggest you avoid this in hot weather.

text: I have been to the Deutsches Museum at least 10 times, as I have live in Munich on and off for the past 25 years!
